Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral dissertation research: The representation, organization and access of lexical tone by native and nonnative Mandarin speakers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
China and its over 1 billion Mandarin speakers play an increasingly important role in global affairs. Today more and more Americans of all ages are engaging with China by learning Mandarin as a foreign language. Yet, learning Mandarin poses many unique challenges; perhaps most daunting is the use of lexical tone, or pitch, to differentiate word meanings. Each syllable in Mandarin can be produced with up to four different pitch patterns--a sharp drop in a speaker's pitch could be the only difference between saying 'four' and 'to die.' Furthermore, tone can vary greatly according to a speaker's gender, age, speaking rate, as well as the position in the utterance and neighboring sounds. Given this complexity in the speech signal, how do native speakers of Mandarin effortlessly and rapidly process tone and how can non-native learners improve these processes? One solution involves probabilistic predictions about speech given the listener's knowledge of Mandarin's distributional properties. All languages exhibit regularly occurring patterns in speech: certain combinations of sounds are highly predictable based on prior experience with the language. Previous work by this research team has shown that native Mandarin speakers are highly sensitive to which tones pattern with which syllables and make use of this statistical learning during word recognition.

Building on this research team's previous work, this project will examine how native and non-native Mandarin speakers store mental information about tones for newly learned words and how this information influences word recognition. This research will test 3 groups of speakers-- native Mandarin speakers, and native English speakers who either are learning Mandarin as a second language or have no previous experience with a tonal language. Participants will take part in a four-day artificial tonal language-learning paradigm. Specifically, the investigators will manipulate the co-occurrence of syllables and tones, as well as the number of speakers a participant hears, in order to monitor each group's sensitivity to the statistical distribution of the artificial language. Participants' word identification, pronunciation, and online eye-movement responses to speech stimuli will be measured across multiple sessions. This research program has implications not just for our cognitive understanding of how lexical tone is learned and used during word recognition, but also for our understanding of how to better teach and acquire a new tonal language like Mandarin Chinese.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In an increasingly interconnected world, bilingual speakers are needed to facilitate the exchange of information across geopolitical and linguistic borders. In particular, the world's two largest economies -- the United States and China -- require proficient English-Mandarin bilinguals to ensure productive and mutually beneficial cooperation into the next decade. As a result, more Americans are learning Mandarin as a foreign language. Yet, Mandarin poses many unique linguistic challenges to learners. In fact, the US Foreign Service Institute ranks Mandarin as one of the most difficult languages for native English speakers to learn. One reason Mandarin is so difficult for non-native learners to acquire is the use of a speaker's pitch or tone to convey word meaning. For instance, the syllable 'ba' can mean 'eight' when spoken with a high level tone or 'father' when spoken with a falling tone. Word-specific tone can vary greatly according to a speaker's gender, age, speaking rate, and the neighboring sounds in an utterance. Many non-native learners of Mandarin abandon the language entirely because they feel they are unable to perceive or produce the tonal contrasts. Since our theoretical understanding of linguistics is largely informed by European languages, like English, Mandarin serves as an important test language. For example, established cognitive models of learning and processing are often unable to account for tone's role in word recognition. Similarly, since most Chinese as a foreign language programs were only recently established, pedagogical materials are often imported from other European languages. Evidence-based, Chinese specific pedagogical materials are still needed to help improve student learning.

This doctoral dissertation research aimed to improve our theoretical understanding of how tone is learned and used during word recognition, as well as improve our models of teaching Mandarin as a foreign language. To accomplish these goals, native Mandarin speakers, native English speakers learning Mandarin as a second language, and monolingual English speakers took part in a four-day artificial language learning experiment. This artificial language was modeled on Mandarin thereby allowing us to examine how learners acquire a Mandarin-like tonal language in a reduced period of time.

Our study revealed that listeners with prior tonal experience can make rapid predictions about which tones are most likely to co-occur with particular syllables and use these predictions to overcome variability in the speech signal. For example, a listener may predict that the syllable 'ba' is more likely to occur with a falling tone given prior experience with 'ba' in Mandarin speech. The intellectual merit of this finding is that it bolsters models of probability-based learning and suggests a memory structure that maximizes regularly occurring patterns in speech.

Our study also revealed two important pedagogical innovations that could have broader impact on the learning of Mandarin as a foreign language. First, by explicitly drawing naive learners' awareness to Mandarin tone contours, learners better perceive and produce tonal contrasts (as compared to a control group of learners who had an implicit awareness of tone). Explicit awareness also facilitates probability-based learning. This suggests that explicit awareness to new speech cues can trigger a statistical learning mechanism in early learners, which can lead to improved perception and production over time. Second, our study revealed that learning tone from multiple speakers, (i.e., high variability speech training) facilitates probability-based learning and leads to increased tonal perception and production abilities as compared to a control group who were exposed to only one speaker. This finding supports the claim that early learners of non-native speech cues benefit from exposure to multiple speakers and highly variable speech as a means of categorical learning. This finding also corroborates child language acquisition studies and suggests that multi-speaker, high variability input may be a crucial piece of the language acquisition puzzle.
